newsitem.title: INDIA: India to build controversial ballistic missile.
newsitem.headline: India to build controversial ballistic missile.

text.p: India pledged on Wednesday to give high priority to building a controversial ballistic missile after announcing last year it was mothballing the project.
"With three flight tests, the re-entry technology demonstration under project Agni has been successfully completed," Defence Minister Mulayam Singh Yadav told parliament.
"It has been decided to accord high priority to the next phase of the Agni programme," Yadav said.

India said last December it had completed testing the intermediate-range Agni but did not plan to build the missile, apparently under pressure from the United States and other countries opposed to India's missile programme.
A parliamentary panel in April urged the government to press ahead with the project, saying it was essential for India's national security.

The 2,500-km (1,500-mile) range Agni is believed capable of carrying a nuclear warhead and is regarded as a potential deterrent to nuclear-armed China, which shares a long Himalayan border with India.
China and India fought a brief war in 1962 and analysts say China's first nuclear test two years later prompted India's only nuclear test in 1974.

India last tested the 14-tonne, 19-metre (60-foot) Agni in 1994. Yadav was replying to an opposition lawmaker's question on whether the country had shelved the Agni missile project under international pressure.
The United States has urged New Delhi to halt missile testing permanently, fearing an arms race in South Asia.
Neighbours India and Pakistan, who have fought three wars since 1947, say they have not built nuclear weapons, but experts say both countries can swiftly assemble them.
"The government is not reconsidering changes in its policy for development of nuclear technology for defence proposals," Yadav said in a written reply.

Junior Defence Minister N.V.N. Somu said the government had received a proposal for developing an integrated anti-missile defence system, but it was not in the interests of national security to give further details.
